text: this is Georgia a former Soviet republic
in the Caucasus Mountains it's been a
favorite vacation spot since the time of
the Czar's this is Julie Dresner for the
New York Times I came here recently with
my family to see why we didn't stay at a
resort or a hotel we wanted to
experience life in the countryside to
get a glimpse of how agriculture is
reviving two decades after communism
fall so we went to a small village
called Sinan dolly in a region famed for
its vineyards and wine agritourism is
new to Georgia but is growing farms are
throwing open their doors to visitors
who want to help tend the crops chop
wood for the stove and bake bread but
who also want a little pampering after
all Georgia is known for its food wine
and hospitality not long into our first
walk around the village a woman gave us
a favorite sweet called church hella we
came to think of it as a Georgian
Snickers bar later we learned to make
them we dipped strings of walnuts into
thickened grape juice then let them dry
meanwhile our hosts have prepared a
feast we were joined at every meal by
the patriarch of the family rivage and
Nicholas really what else you're
beautiful just hear that she's a lot of
Silverado crush there was a roasted
pepper and eggplant both served with the
walnut pesto and George and dumplings
called khinkali when we asked about the
recipes we were invited into the kitchen
for a masterclass
we learned how to bake bread and a wood
fire outdoor kill even the wine was
homemade vaja showed us how his family
makes there's which they stored a large
sister no I should be is raja loves
everything about wine my kids wanted to
put him to the test we had read about
blindfolded experts it could not tell
the difference between red and white
wines he was not to be fooled a typical
Georgian meal is peppered with many
toasts as we finished hours vaja offered
us these form words no way is it weeds
out now Watson us don't you say that oh
just my pleasure so what's another table
